results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to explore bias in a predictive machine learning model related to student ADHD status. The methodology involves combining fairness metrics with XAI techniques.
Sections 3 and 4 provide a detailed step-by-step description of the study design, including the online learning platform, data collection, feature engineering, model training, and analysis methods.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.
While the document doesn't explicitly state a reason for not sharing data, it implies privacy concerns by mentioning IRB approval and the option for participants to not answer sensitive questions.

Section 3.2 and 4.1 provide details about the data collected, including demographic information, OSLQ survey details, and features extracted for the model. The description of the OSLQ subscales acts as a partial codebook.
Section 3.2 details the data collection methods, including recruitment from a university and Prolific, compensation details, and the use of a consent form and demographic survey.
The document does not mention whether the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
No justification is provided for not sharing the code.
The document does not explicitly state whether code for data preparation is shared.
The document clearly describes the statistical tests (regression analysis), models (random forest regression), and assumptions used in the analysis (Section 4.1 and 4.2).
Effect sizes (R2 = .481) and statistical significance (p-values) are reported throughout the results section (Section 4.1 and 5.2).
The document primarily focuses on quantitative analysis and lacks substantial subjective context or interpretation beyond the statistical findings.
No qualitative data coding or analysis is described or shared.
The results are clearly presented in sections 5.1 and 5.2, with tables and descriptions of the findings related to fairness metrics and SHAP value correlations.
Section 6 discusses limitations, including the sample size of students with ADHD and the lack of qualitative data. Potential biases are also acknowledged throughout the discussion.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
